And for a lot of those people, they like checked in, you know, they saw ChatGPT became big, they checked out you know, a year and a half ago, and they’re like, “Oh, this thing can kind of do these little party tricks, I can you know, talk back to me, can you know, I don’t know,  write write a business email. Um, I use this stuff every day, and I also, I make it a point very intentionally to find more reasons to use AI. Not because I think I actually need it on a day to day basis, like, I’m actually somebody who you know, for the most part, I’m actually really good at a lot of things AIs are already good at. Like, I’m very good at writing, I’m very good at math, you know, jamming out emails really quickly, which I know a lot of people struggle with. Um, but, the reason why I want to keep using it over and over again is that I want to grow with it. I want to learn it as it changes and improves, and see what skills it forces me to get good at. In the same way the people who were Googling in like the early 2000s and learned how to use Google, and how to work with Google, and like, how to like how to do searches, right? Because you talk to somebody, like I don’t know your your your parents or your grandparents and you watch them Google, and you’re just like, “What are you doing?” like, you you just have no mental model of what this thing wants, and like, how to interact with it. Um, and this is one of these technologies that you you got to grow alongside it. And you got to learn as it teaches you how to use it and how to change alongside it. Um, and just very simple things of like, “Can you even describe what you want? Do you know what you want? And then, you have people who don’t really use this stuff, and as a result, they’re either bored and they think it’s all stupid, or they’re just gobsmacked, and they believe it can do anything.
